Using the distributive rule (5) A | (B & C) ::=:: (A | B) & (A | C), we can rewrite ((!p | q) & (!p | r)) as:
(!p | (!p | q)) & (!p | (!p | r)), which simplifies to !p & (!p | (q | r)).

Since !p & (!p | (q | r)) is equivalent to !p (by rule (7) A & (A | B) ::=:: A), and !p is equivalent to !p | (q | r) (also by rule (7)), we have:
((!p | q) & (!p | r)) ::=:: !p | (q | r).

**!(p=q)::=::(p|q)&!(p&q)**

(p > q) & (q > p).

- p > q ::=:: !p | q

Now, we need to check if !((!p | q) & (!q | p)) is equivalent to (p | q) & !(p & q).

Using rule (6) !(A & B) ::=:: !A | !B, we rewrite !((!p | q) & (!q | p)) as:
!(!p | q) | !(!q | p).

Similarly, !(!q | p) ::=:: q & !p.

So, !((!p | q) & (!q | p)) becomes (p & !q) | (q & !p).

We need to check if (p & !q) | (q & !p) is equivalent to (p | q) & !(p & q).
